content.title: RENEWABLE ENERGY FOR ENHANCING CLIMATE RESILIENCE

content.text: Lesson 1 Overview
RENEWABLE ENERGY FOR ENHANCING CLIMATE RESILIENCE

Climate change is introducing unprecedented challenges and uncertainties, demanding that energy systems become more flexible, robust, and prepared to withstand extreme weather events, temperature variations, and shifting environmental conditions. As the frequency and intensity of climate-related risks increase—ranging from hurricanes and floods to prolonged droughts and heatwaves—the need to enhance the resilience and adaptability of energy systems has never been more critical. Ensuring a reliable, sustainable, and secure energy supply is essential for both mitigating the impacts of climate change and supporting communities in adapting to its effects.

At the same time, sustainable energy solutions offer a dual benefit: they not only reduce greenhouse gas emissions, a key driver of climate change, but also serve as powerful tools for climate adaptation and resilience-building. By leveraging renewable energy sources, improving energy efficiency, and developing resilient energy infrastructure, communities can better adapt to the impacts of climate change. These solutions also support economic development, improve energy access, and make sustainable energy systems more affordable, particularly for vulnerable populations who are often the most affected by climate-related disruptions.
In this lesson, we explore how renewable energy can enhance climate resilience across various sectors—from water and food security to emergency response and economic stability. Through real-world examples and case studies, we demonstrate the transformative potential of decentralized, sustainable energy systems in building resilient communities and safeguarding critical infrastructure in the face of a changing climate.

content.title: Part 1: Energy Uses in Climate Adaptation

content.text: It is often the case that those without access to electricity are the most vulnerable to climate change. Decentralized energy assets play a critical role in climate adaptation and in promoting initiatives that enhance resilience as well as food security. This is emphasized by the COP 27 Sharm El-Sheikh Adaptation Agenda, which lists achieving universal access to electricity through climate-smart and resilient energy systems as one of its 30 key goals.
Water, Food and Agriculture

Off-grid technologies offer decentralized and democratized access to electricity, making them more resilient to climate risks. For instance, solar energy kits and irrigation systems are portable and less reliant on extensive distribution networks, making them less susceptible to floods, high winds, and cyclones. They are also less susceptible to blackouts during heat waves. Parallelly, access to productive use of renewable energy (PURE) technologies is also enhancing resilience.
The sustainable energy interventions in the agriculture sector optimize crop yield, creating more resilient communities while achieving universal access ambitions. Solar irrigation systems promote sustainable use of water resources, thereby reducing reliance on rain-fed traditional agriculture practices. In Bangladesh, for example, the community improved their resilience to the drought gripping their region by installing 12 solar-powered tube wells to pump, store in a 5,000-liter master tank, and distribute water to their homes. Additionally, solar-powered cold storage systems provide a transformative solution supporting food security initiatives by extending the shelf life of perishable food. For instance, Ecozen Solutions specializes in portable solar cold rooms in India.
Emergency Response and Resilience

Renewable energy significantly enhances community resilience to climate disasters. Decentralized renewable systems provide crucial backup power for emergency services and critical infrastructure when conventional power fails. For instance, mini and micro-hydro systems can generate electricity for remote communities while also supporting flood mitigation efforts. Additionally, early warning systems powered by renewables help communities prepare for extreme weather events. For displaced populations, mobile renewable solutions offer quick deployment of essential services in emergency settlements.
Case Study RBLAC:                                                                                                                  Kazakhstan —Wind Power Market Development Initiative

The town of Adjuntas in Puerto Rico has become a notable example of how decentralized energy solutions can enhance community resilience, particularly in regions vulnerable to climate-related disruptions. Solar microgrids, which generate electricity locally using solar energy, have reduced Adjuntas’ reliance on centralized power plants and transmission lines, which are often susceptible to damage during extreme weather events. This localized approach not only ensures a more reliable energy supply but also offers scalability, allowing communities to expand their energy capacity as needed. 
The need for such a solution became evident after Hurricane Maria in 2017, which left Adjuntas without power for six months. In response, the local community organization Casa Pueblo, in partnership with the nonprofit Honnold Foundation, installed solar-powered microgrids. These microgrids demonstrated their effectiveness during Hurricane Fiona in September 2022, providing uninterrupted power to critical facilities for nine days while other parts of Puerto Rico experienced widespread outages. This achievement highlights the potential of renewable energy to improve community resilience and adapt to the growing risks posed by climate change.

The success of the Adjuntas microgrids is rooted in strong community involvement and collaboration. The establishment of the Community Solar Energy Association of Adjuntas (ACESA), a nonprofit led by ten local business owners, has ensured that the microgrids are managed by the community itself. This model has not only reduced electricity costs for small businesses but also created a sustainable framework for future energy projects. Excess funds generated from microgrids are reinvested into community solar initiatives, fostering long-term energy independence.  
Despite challenges such as supply chain disruptions and the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, the Adjuntas community has remained committed to the project. The installation of 1,000 solar panels has provided a reliable energy source and set a precedent for other communities facing similar vulnerabilities.

The Adjuntas microgrid initiative demonstrates how renewable energy can address immediate energy needs while building long-term resilience. By decentralizing energy production and empowering local communities, the project has not only mitigated the effects of extreme weather but also created a sustainable model for energy independence. This case study offers valuable insights for other regions seeking to enhance their resilience through community-driven renewable energy solutions. 
As Adjuntas continues to develop its microgrid infrastructure, ongoing support from stakeholders and partners will be crucial to scaling the project and ensuring its long-term success. The initiative serves as a practical example of how renewable energy can strengthen communities and provide a reliable energy supply in the face of climate challenges.

content.intro: M6: SUSTAINABLE ENERGY FOR CLIMATE MITIGATION | chapter 2 | Lesson 1 | Part 2
content.title: Part 2: Off-Grid Renewable Energy: Strengthening Resilience and Economic Stability

content.text:
For communities without reliable grid access, decentralized renewable energy is a necessary infrastructure for stability and adaptation. In regions where climate change disrupts traditional livelihoods and energy security, off-grid systems provide a practical solution for sustaining essential services, supporting local economies, and reducing dependence on costly and unreliable fuel imports. This is critically interconnected to the 2030 Agenda, as highlighted in the previous modules. 
Beyond basic electrification, off-grid energy solutions enable local enterprises and institutions to operate with greater predictability. Micro, Small, and Medium-sized Enterprises (MSMEs) play a critical role in economic development, contributing significantly to employment and GDP. Their reliance on energy-intensive operations makes decentralized renewable energy crucial for cost reduction, resilience, and sustainability. More than 10 million micro, small, and medium-sized enterprises (MSMEs) currently integrate decentralized energy technologies, using them to lower costs, expand services, and improve climate resilience. In many cases, the transition to renewable energy is not simply about replacing fossil fuels but about reshaping local energy governance, ensuring that communities can control and maintain their own power systems without external dependencies.
Water Access and Resource Stability

In arid and coastal regions, climate change increasingly affects freshwater availability. Solar-powered water desalination and pumping systems provide a reliable solution, reducing reliance on rain-fed water supplies and mitigating the risks associated with droughts and changing precipitation patterns.   In Bangladesh, solar-powered irrigation has allowed farming communities to shift away from unreliable rainfall, improving agricultural output and reducing the need for expensive diesel-based pumping systems. Similar approaches are being adopted in Sub-Saharan Africa, where solar water pumps are improving access to drinking water and irrigation without the high operating costs of conventional power systems.
Sustainable Cooling

Access to cooling technologies is often overlooked in energy planning, despite its critical role in wellbeing, food security, healthcare, and commerce. The world is warming, with record-breaking temperatures and increasing and projected increases in the intensity and duration of heat waves globally. According to the World Meteorological Organization (WMO), 2024 was the warmest year on record, with climate change adding 41 days of extreme heat. Higher temperatures have far-reaching impacts on people’s health and well-being, work productivity, energy systems and the natural environment. In fact, heat-associated mortalities saw a 68% increase between 2000-04 and 2017-21. Beyond health consequences, rising heat stress is projected to cost USD 2.4 trillion of global GDP in 2030. Hence, it is no surprise that extreme heat events are both short- and long-term risks, as identified by the World Economic Forum.

In the face of increasing temperatures, cooling is now more critical than ever to ensure people’s well-being, keep food and vaccines safe and economies functioning. Cooling demand is expected to triple by 2050, increasing electricity usage and in turn, greenhouse gas emissions. Business-as-usual cooling, i.e., with active cooling equipment such as air conditioners, lock us into a vicious cycle of heating and cooling, representing a double burden. For instance, air conditioning accounts for around 7% of global GHG emissions. Therefore, the imperative at hand is to transform how we cool by ensuring this is sustainable. Sustainable cooling is an opportunity area with both mitigation and adaptation benefits. Besides, it directly influences other sustainable development outcomes, including the energy transition, health and food security. In fact, sustainable cooling can support over 1 billion people in adapting to climate risks while reducing the energy transition costs by USD 3.5 trillion by 2030.
Energy for Healthcare and Public Services

Medical facilities in off-grid or disaster-prone areas depend on stable energy access for critical services, including vaccine refrigeration, diagnostic equipment, and surgical operations. Without reliable power, healthcare delivery is severely compromised. In crisis contexts, reliable electricity is essential for healthcare facilities to function effectively. In sub-Saharan Africa, 25% of health centers lack electricity, leaving critical services such as vaccine storage, emergency procedures, and maternal care at risk. Extreme weather events, intensified by climate change, further strain healthcare infrastructure, increasing hospitalizations due to heatwaves and air pollution. Decentralized renewable energy systems can bridge this gap, ensuring uninterrupted medical care and strengthening health resilience in vulnerable regions. Solar-powered clinics are being deployed in regions affected by extreme weather events, ensuring that disruptions to grid electricity do not translate into disruptions in medical care. For example, the Solar for Health initiative has equipped health facilities in 15 countries with solar power, ensuring reliable electricity for critical medical services while reducing reliance on unstable grids and costly diesel.
Economic Development and Energy Access for Enterprises

Reliable electricity is a prerequisite for economic diversification. Small businesses, cooperatives, and local manufacturing facilities depend on affordable and consistent power to operate machinery, process raw materials, and expand production capacity. In regions where grid extension is economically unfeasible, decentralized renewable energy provides a viable alternative for business development. For example, in Puerto Rico, locally managed solar microgrids have allowed small businesses to remain operational during grid outages. This model not only reduces exposure to energy price volatility but also reinvests surplus revenue into further energy development, demonstrating the economic advantages of community-led renewable initiatives.
Supporting Livelihoods and Climate-Smart Growth in Vulnerable Regions

Small island nations and coastal communities face unique challenges from climate change, including rising sea levels, saltwater intrusion, and extreme weather events. In these contexts, renewable energy enables vital adaptation through small-scale desalination systems, hydrothermal cooling using seawater, and power for eco-tourism operations. In remote and underserved areas, renewable solutions support basic healthcare through reliable power for medical facilities, vaccine cold chains, and water purification systems. These technologies not only enhance resilience but also create opportunities for sustainable livelihoods, helping communities thrive in the face of climate challenges.

content.title: Part 3:  Implementation Framework for Sustainable Energy Solutions

content.text:
The successful deployment of sustainable energy solutions requires a strategic and context-sensitive approach. While the potential of renewable energy to enhance climate resilience is well-documented, its effective implementation hinges on addressing local needs, building cross-sector collaboration, and ensuring long-term sustainability.
Sustainable energy solutions often intersect with other sectors, such as water, agriculture, and healthcare. Cross-sector coordination is essential to maximize the impact of these solutions and avoid maladaptation risks. For instance, solar-powered irrigation systems can simultaneously address water scarcity, improve agricultural productivity, and reduce reliance on fossil fuels. Similarly, decentralized energy systems can support healthcare delivery by powering medical facilities and vaccine cold chains in off-grid areas. Effective coordination requires clear communication, shared goals, and partnerships between governments, NGOs, and private sector actors.

Long-term sustainability depends on robust policy frameworks that support the deployment and maintenance of sustainable energy solutions. Governments must prioritize the integration of renewable energy into national adaptation plans (NAPs) and ensure that policies are aligned with locally led adaptation principles. For example, Mozambique’s NAP highlights the importance of mobilizing women-led community organizations in adaptation planning, demonstrating how gender-responsive policies can enhance resilience. Strengthening commitments to gender equality and social inclusion (GESI) in energy policies can further ensure that the benefits of sustainable energy reach the most vulnerable populations.
Community-Based Adaptation

Community-based adaptation (CBA) is a proven approach to building resilience as seen in the previous modules, particularly in regions where vulnerable populations face the brunt of climate change impacts. CBA involves processes led by local actors, including subnational authorities, civil society organizations, community groups and youth to identify adaptation priorities and implement solutions tailored to local contexts. This approach leverages local knowledge while fostering inclusive governance, ensuring that marginalized groups are actively involved in decision-making.

In Southern Africa, CBA has demonstrated its potential to reduce climate risks and generate sustainable changes for vulnerable communities. For example, in Mozambique, women-led community organizations have been mobilized to participate in adaptation planning, ensuring that energy solutions address gender-specific needs, such as access to clean water and healthcare. Similarly, in Zambia, solar-powered irrigation systems have been co-designed with local farmers to improve agricultural resilience while reducing reliance on costly and unreliable diesel pumps. In other instance, the Justice40 Initiative, led by RMI, demonstrates real-world applications of Community Benefit Agreements (CBA) by ensuring that at least 40% of federal clean energy investments benefit disadvantaged communities.

cards.title: Renewable Energy Enhances Resilience Through Decentralized Solutions.
cards.description: Beyond reducing emissions, renewable energy can strengthen resilience by providing decentralized, climate-smart solutions. Off-grid solar irrigation, cold storage, and microgrids improve water access, food security, and economic stability, particularly in vulnerable regions.

cards.title: Decentralized Energy Systems Mitigate Disaster Risks.
cards.description: Decentralized energy systems can be effective against natural disasters, especially under a changing climate. Renewable-powered microgrids, solar backup systems, and climate-resilient energy infrastructure help maintain critical services during extreme weather events.

cards.title: Strategic Planning is Essential for Effective Deployment.
cards.description: Effective deployment of renewable energy solutions requires careful planning to ensure they enhance resilience rather than inadvertently increasing vulnerabilities. Tailoring solutions to local climate risks, resource availability, and economic conditions helps avoid unintended negative consequences.

lessons.title:
Bracing for Climate Impact: Renewables as a Climate Change Adaptation Strategy 
This paper explores the role of renewable energy in climate adaptation, highlighting its potential to enhance resilience while supporting mitigation efforts. It examines strategic integration into adaptation planning, financing, and sectoral applications, illustrating how renewables can address climate risks across water, food, disaster response, health, and coastal systems

Good Practices for Designing Effective, Inclusive, and Sustainable Nature-Based Solutions for Adaptation
This report provides a framework for assessing nature-based solutions (NbS) for climate change adaptation, focusing on good practices for gender responsiveness, social inclusivity, and conflict sensitivity. It helps practitioners and policymakers design and evaluate effective, sustainable projects by aligning them with internationally recognized principles and standards.

Climate action and the energy transition: IRENA Member survey on NDCs
This report examines the upcoming NDC 3.0 submissions, focusing on how countries plan to integrate the COP28 goal of tripling renewables by 2030 into their national targets. Based on a survey of 51 IRENA members, it highlights key challenges, priorities, and support needs for NDC enhancement, implementation, and long-term low-emission strategies.
